persona.name: Gloria
persona.activities: Gloria likes using personalised services which help her organising her tasks. This holds for Internet-based services as well as for services offered by shops, restaurants and others. To ease her life with her allergies, she uses her mobile phone and related services to find food she can eat. Her profession is policy decision maker. She is an employee of an e-book store, deciding and implementing access and distribution policies for e-books.
persona.attitudes: In order to extract interesting offers she likes filtering the vast amount of offers by subscribing for information about promotions and special deals of her favourite shops. She also participates in providing useful information by writing recommendations for restaurants. On her job, it is important for her to provide attractive products. She wants her customers to enjoy reading their e-books. In her policies she allows them to read their books on any of their devices.
persona.motivations: Her private life -- her hobbies and her interests -- is what she is living for. Everything else is centred around. She enjoys shopping and dining out. She uses mobile devices and mobile services if they improve her experience of her interests. Her hobbies are even more important than her friends. She seems to enjoy herself best when she is alone. Presumably she is a single. Her job appears to provide her with enough money to be spent on her hobbies.

persona_environment.narrative: Gloria is not that computer-addicted, but she is very aware of privacy. When using online services and applications, she sets the privacy settings and she keeps separate identities for personal life and work. Her expertise on privacy is related to her job.

document_reference.name: Works on implementing policies (data access, privacy)
document_reference.document: Manageable privacy policies across the application lifecycle User Story
document_reference.excerpt:
He has been asked to write several policies governing the e-books and the application itself.

The company has realised that a mistake was made in their original terms and conditions and a related data-access policy. He has to push a new version of these terms and a new policy to all customers. 

He is then asked to implement a new pricing model and also to update the prices of some books. 

For certain books, users can pay nothing so long as they agree to advertising and report click-through frequency and a few other details.

One of Aaron’s concerns when collecting statistics on advertising information is that spoofing is prevented.

document_reference.name: Keeps work and personal life separate in her online identities
document_reference.document: Manageable privacy policies across the application lifecycle User Story
document_reference.excerpt:
She has many online identities, but likes to keep her work and personal life separate. 

When using her mobile phone for work she switches to her Linked In identity, and during the weekends she moves to her Facebook-provided identity.

Jane thinks that this sounds fantastic, and agrees to share her allergy information, stored on her mobile. However, she also specifies that this information should not be shared with any other applications. 

She makes sure that this is done from her personal online identity, as she does not want her company to be seen to be endorsing this restaurant.

Jane gets home and decides to make sure her personal information is suitable protected by editing the privacy policy. She uses webinos to restrict which applications may have access to her name, online identity, current location and device information.

document_reference.name: Privacy-aware user
document_reference.document: Manageable privacy policies across the application lifecycle User Story
document_reference.excerpt:
She has many online identities, but likes to keep her work and personal life separate. 

Jane thinks that this sounds fantastic, and agrees to share her allergy information, stored on her mobile. However, she also specifies that this information should not be shared with any other applications. 

She makes sure that this is done from her personal online identity, as she does not want her company to be seen to be endorsing this restaurant.

Jane gets home and decides to make sure her personal information is suitable protected by editing the privacy policy. She uses webinos to restrict which applications may have access to her name, online identity, current location and device information.

Sometimes, Jane wants a little more privacy. She may temporarily have a medical condition that she wants to track but does not want to share, or she may be shopping somewhere more risqué, or shopping for a surprise present. She configures a new policy in webinos that will not keep records of what she is doing and where she is going, and will keep her devices hidden from nearby networks.
